title: Ask HN: Twitter was unanimously predicted to implode. Nothing happened. Why?
text:
Twitter laid off 50% of its staff. Principal and staff engineers made lengthy Twitter threads predicting the collapse of the system given its nuance, complexity, and how their positions were key to its survival. Pundits predicted that the site would likely not survive a few weeks, that there was no fat to trim at the company and all the workers let go were essential for daily operations.

Now that it's been three months, what happened to the dreary prognosis? Where is the continuous downtime? Where is the permanent feature freeze? Where is the imminent collapse we were told about? I noticed that nobody is talking about how none of those predictions seem to have manifested. Why?

title: Ask HN: Does the HN commentariat have a reductive view of what a human being is?
text:
I've been very struck during most of the AI discussions recently how little weight comments seem give to the subtlety and rich contextual knowledge that humans bring to even quite simple activities.

I know we often over-estimate the value of our contributions. I know we often find that our functions can ultimately be automated in some respect. But I find in aggregate that the leading comments reflect a very arid conception of being a human connected to other humans.

For example in the discussion about AI Lawyers very little sense of the moral aspect of another human acting on behalf of a human client. In the discussions about the replacement of programming jobs by this kind of technology, not a great deal of confidence in the importance of human judgement in building human-focused systems.

Is this just reflective of our context as people that streamline and automate, or do HN readers just think a human isn't such a complex entity?

For me this is somewhat like the T-Shirt that says "I went outside once, but the graphics were crap"...except nobody's joking.

Crazydomains web GUI zone records out of sync with their Name Servers for hours
text:
Recently, I started to have huge issue with my domains which I'm hosting in Crazydomains company (https://www.crazydomains.co.uk). I was trying to upgrade TXT record in one of them and I found that even if I edit zone using their web gui, this doesn't have any reflection on what their Name Servers (ns1.crazydomains.com & ns2.crazydomains.com) serve. I was trying to give a time around 1 hour to apply changes which I made, but after that time, running query directly against Crazydomains DNS servers shows that changes haven't been applied.

I opened ticked with them, and they told me that it will make 2-4 hours to apply my changes made by web gui. It's quite long time for wait, but I did wait until next day. In mean time, someone from Crazydomains support decide to switch default name servers in my domain to Premium one as I have this option under my account, which completely cut off DNS resolution to all my services, as Premium Name Servers have no knowledge about my domain. I had to open another ticket about this .

Next day, my TXT record was still not updated so I follow with primary ticket, and send back and forward updates about this issue. Next day, 48 hours after record change, it was still not updated in Crazydomains Name Servers. I contacted them, and they magically "did something" (I guess reload zone manually) and record was updated.

I decide to run test and I modified TXT record again 5 hours ago, and situation is time same - in web gui record is updated but on their Name Servers not.

Does anybody experiencing or experienced this same issue with Crazydomains ???
